summary: Email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys regarding proposed jury instructions and redactions for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. The correspondence discusses procedural issues, deadlines, and disputes over the anonymization of victim names in court filings.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell corresponding with prosecutors about jury instructions, redactions, and objecting to anonymizing victim names.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, mentioned in the email chain as a recipient.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on the email correspondence.

connections.description: Both are defense attorneys representing Ghislaine Maxwell, collaborating on trial preparations.
Both are defense attorneys on Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team, copied on case correspondence.

events.title: Jury Instruction Deadline
events.description: Deadline for submitting proposed jury instructions and redactions to motions in limine (MILs) for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, New York
keyFacts: Defense attorneys objected to anonymizing victim names in court filings, insisting on using their actual names despite prosecution concerns about privacy and redaction burdens.
The defense had missed deadlines for submitting proposed jury instructions, prompting discussion about seeking an extension from the court.
Prosecutors expressed concern that the defense's practice of using victim names in filings risked accidentally revealing victim identities if redactions were missed.
